Headlines:
• Stocks sank for the second straight session on May 12 as inflationary concerns weighed heavily on investors, with the Dow industrials down nearly 120 points and the Nasdaq composite losing more than 2 percent.
  • Gold peaked at $750 an ounce on May 12, while crude neared $80 over the summer, as commodities rallied amid geopolitical tensions and strong demand from emerging markets.
  • The Federal Reserve raised its key interest rate by a quarter-percentage point to 5 percent on May 10, marking its 16th consecutive increase since June 2004. The Fed said that some further policy firming may be needed but also signaled a possible pause in its tightening cycle.

Financial markets - May 2006

  • Financial market environment: Improved expectations for the global economy despite higher energy prices.
  • Bond markets: Yields rose in most regions as inflation concerns increased.
  • Equity markets: Strong earnings supported stock prices until mid-May, when volatility spiked amid global sell-off.
  • Credit markets: Spreads widened slightly but remained near historical lows.
  • Foreign exchange markets: The euro and the yen appreciated against the US dollar.

Financial Market Update, June 2006 - International Monetary Fund

  • The update covers developments in both mature and emerging markets.
  • The update highlights the risks and challenges posed by a sudden shift in market sentiment.
  • The update discusses policy implications for maintaining financial stability.
    • "

European stocks ended modestly higher on July 1, with Britain's FTSE 100 rising 0.7%, the DAX in Germany and France's CAC 40 adding 0.6%[^2^][1]. However, the stock market crashed later that month, losing about 28% of its value from July 22 to August 9 due to concerns over the U.S. debt ceiling and the European debt crisis[^3^][2]. The market did bounce off that low and then resumed its downward trend until October.

The European debt crisis, also known as the Eurozone crisis, began in late 2009 and lasted through much of the 2010s. In 2011, the crisis reached a critical point, with several European countries facing the possibility of defaulting on their sovereign debt.

The crisis was triggered by a combination of factors, including high levels of government debt, low economic growth, and the global financial crisis of 2008. The crisis affected several countries in the European Union, including Greece, Ireland, Portugal, Spain, and Italy.

The crisis led to a number of measures being taken by the European Union and its member states to address the situation. These measures included the creation of the European Stability Mechanism, which provided financial assistance to countries in need, and the implementation of austerity measures in affected countries.

The crisis had a significant impact on the European economy and led to high levels of unemployment, particularly in countries like Greece and Spain. It also had political ramifications, with some countries questioning the viability of the European Union and the euro currency. While the crisis has largely receded in recent years, its effects are still being felt in some parts of Europe.

• The terrorist attacks in Paris on November 13 killed 130 people and wounded hundreds more1. The attacks sparked fear and uncertainty among investors and consumers, as well as solidarity and resilience among world leaders.
  • The European Central Bank (ECB) disappointed markets on November 25 by announcing a smaller-than-expected stimulus package1. The ECB cut its deposit rate by 10 basis points to -0.3% and extended its bond-buying program by six months, but did not increase the monthly amount of purchases.
  • China’s economy continued to show signs of slowing down, as its official manufacturing Purchasing Managers’ Index (PMI) fell to 49.6 in November, below the 50 level that separates expansion from contraction2. China’s weak growth raised concerns about its impact on global demand and commodity prices.
  • The U.S. economy added 271,000 jobs in October, beating expectations and boosting the case for a Fed rate hike in December3. The unemployment rate fell to 5%, the lowest since April 2008, and wages rose by 2.5% year-over-year, the fastest pace since July 2009.

• The Federal Reserve raised its benchmark interest rate for the first time in nearly a decade, signaling confidence in the U.S. economy and ending an era of near-zero rates.
  • China’s stock market plunged more than 20% from its peak in June, triggering circuit breakers and spooking global investors about the health of the world’s second-largest economy.
  • Oil prices continued to slide to their lowest levels since 2009, amid oversupply and weak demand. The collapse in oil prices impacted all other assets, especially energy stocks and emerging markets.
  • Greece reached a deal with its creditors to avoid a default and stay in the eurozone, after months of uncertainty and turmoil that rattled European markets.
  • The U.S. dollar strengthened against most major currencies, as diverging monetary policies boosted its appeal. The strong dollar weighed on U.S. corporate earnings and exports.

• The U.S. and China announced a partial trade deal that would roll back some tariffs and boost Chinese purchases of U.S. agricultural goods.
  • The U.S. economy added 128,000 jobs in October, beating expectations of 89,000 and signaling resilience amid a slowing global growth and trade tensions.
  • The Federal Reserve cut interest rates for the third time this year by 25 basis points to a range of 1.5% to 1.75%, citing muted inflation pressures and uncertainties around trade and global growth.
  • Neil Woodford’s investment firm blocked redemptions from his flagship £3.7bn fund, sparking a crisis in the UK’s fund management industry and raising questions about liquidity and regulation.
  • Saudi Aramco announced its long-awaited initial public offering on the Riyadh stock exchange, aiming to raise up to $25.6bn and valuing the state-owned oil giant at $1.7tn.

• The World Health Organization declared COVID-19 an official pandemic on March 11, 2020. The Dow Jones’ fall of nearly 3,000 points on March 16, 2020, was the largest single-day drop in U.S. stock market history.
  • The S&P 500 entered a bear market on March 12, 2020, ending its longest bull run ever. It dropped more than 20% from its peak on February 19, 2020.
  • Oil prices plunged to their lowest level since 2016 after Saudi Arabia and Russia failed to agree on production cuts amid falling demand due to the coronavirus outbreak. On February 20, 2020, Brent crude oil futures fell below $50 per barrel for the first time since December 2018.
